HBFF stays true to their mission - they live it, breathe it, believe in it, and work it every day. The company is fair, ethical, they do what they say they're going to do, and support employees' desire to move 'up'.  They are very supportive in immersing new employees into the culture and helping us understand the work we do, and the journey of recovery.
Very flexible with schedules, and work/life balance.
cons: A bit old-school, resistant to change.  Most of the administrative staff have been employed at HBFF 15+ years and don't embrace change openly, and are a bit standoffish to new people.  This isn't really a management issue - it's more how a new person handles the challenge of winning others over, and being open to earning trust first - then making changes or sharing ideas for improvement and efficiency later.

job_title: Counselor in Center City, MN
pros: The people I work with at my level are knowledgeable and caring and try to provide high quality care for their clients.  The team one works with can make your job.
cons: In the years I have worked at Hazelden it has devolved from a patient first to insurance first.  I spend much of my time trying to convince strangers the client needs treatment.  My job has not changed when I am with the patient but that is less and less time.  More time is data entry and pretending Hazelden is the" Best Place to Work".  I have watched people I have worked with for years forced into leaving due to restructuring and pay cuts. It doesn't seem to matter because "business decisions" are above people.

review_title: Confusing, disorganized management structure; don't put their money where their mouth is
job_title: in Saint Paul, MN
pros: I loved the patients and recovery.
cons: Badly structured, incredibly poor processes, out-of-touch management, poor benefits, no respect. I had the single worst manager I have ever worked with in 30 years; she didn't know what I did but thought she did because she did the job ten years ago. No matter what I did I couldn't win: if I asked her for her opinion on something, it was useless because she didn't even know what I was talking about, although she pretended to, and if I didn't, I got slammed for not asking.

job_title: Addiction COunselor in New York, NY
pros: Make a difference in the world. Growing addiction problems in the world are a major problem, and it great to be on the front lines.
cons: So hard to capture. Facility is run by addicts, and not in a positive way. I say that as a recovering addict, it just operates like a dysfunctional family. Very poor guidance and support for clinicians. Multiple relapses every week. Extensive fraternization consistently. Staff have learned to not care, quietly, because they are not supported. No innovation or advances in treatment. Don't work here. Don't send love ones here. Send them to AA or Smart Recovery and a counselor and you will get better results. Ask any staff and they will tell you the same thing, if they can be honest with you.

job_title: in Center City, MN
pros: The majority of staff care about the population served.
cons: There is a serious disconnect between the stated mission of Hazelden and actual practice. I moved 800 miles to specifically work at Hazelden, based on the compay's reputation. Whereas the framework for effective management is present, it is not utilized effectively. The company fails to follow the policies in place and unfortunately only pays lip service to improvement through the empowerment of staff. It appeared that long term employees were well aware of the issues, but were wise enough to stay quiet lest they be targeted. The middle management seems very protective of their fifedoms and is quick to stifle any complaint or worse, constructive criticism. It closely resembles a big dysfunctional family. One that uses passive aggression as the favored management technique. I recommend examining turnover rates for a cle as r picture of each department.

job_title: Clinician in Center City, MN
pros: Beautiful campus, and very nice serene wilderness surroundings. Some nice co-workers that are supportive and easy to get along with. Prestigious name of employer.
cons: Horrible management. The management, including directors of nursing are NOT dedicated to staff satisfaction as evidenced by a very large staff turnover rate and people walking out and never coming back. New directives are started to "create efficiency" yet cause slower work flow and yet no support from management. Key front line employees such as long term experienced RNs have been replaced by new graduate inexperienced LPNs. Sketchy patient outcomes. If you speak out against their policies or voice your opinion, they will help you out the door. They show no sorrow for those who leave. Poor benefits. Salaried employees, especially clinicians work day and night to keep up with the patient needs, and at no salary adjustment. No work/life balance at all--its expected.

job_title: Director in Naples, FL
pros: Hazelden Betty Ford is very mission minded.  Haven't worked for an organization like this where people are really passionate about addiction and many very skilled.  Have worked at various sites within the organization and find passionate people throughout.  Organization even focuses on attitudes of employees.  Leaders are being trained on employee engagement.  All staff are trained on customer service...be of service.
cons: Large organization so within it there are varied levels of staff commitment.  At times people have not been held accountable including management but that is strongly changing.  Low performers are being moved out.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Center City, MN
pros: There are a tremendous amount of good people that work for this organization and they truly want to help people. Benefits are great.
cons: Upper management has created a very disorganized system that started with the merger with Betty Ford Center and ended with the implementation of a new EHR from Cerner. It was a complete disaster from the word go. I think they hide the truth from employees about changes and why they take place. There has been restructuring that has adversely effected many employees. It is too bad. This is not the place I knew from may years ago.

job_title: Financial Case Manager in Saint Paul, MN
pros: I was thrilled to be working for the people who started addiction treatment.
cons: Admittedly, addiction treatment was and is a stressful job, and the field was going through huge change at the time I was employed by Hazelden. However, Hazelden had management in place who had zero understanding of the realities of the marketplace and showed no commitment to supporting me in my burning desire to achieve the next-to-impossible. The program I ran was heavily managed-care dependent and we had no professionals in place to do pre-certification or care coordination for step downs. The result was utter chaos, and I was blamed no matter what I did. If I offered a step down to a lower level of care they were mad because those programs were overbooked, if I offered nothing they were mad because we were discharging without a care plan. My case load was ridiculous and I was managed by a woman who didn't understand insurance or financial case management and whose mistakes I regularly covered for.

job_title: Clinical in Center City, MN

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Center City, MN

review_title: Watch your back with the Politburo
job_title: Addiction COunselor in Plymouth, MN
pros: Great facilities in MN, fabulous, dedicated frontline employees (who do the work), dedicated counselors, the vast majority of workers care about patient care.
cons:
I can just echo previous posts & add a couple morsels: the CEO, M Michek is an old 1%er, who doesn't identify with the unwashed; middle management is frequently (usually) incompetent & may have an IQ south of 100; focused on money, not patient care (I completely agree with the poster who cited patients who have far too numerous or severe co-occurring illnesses to be treated at this place (not even close) but are kept because their insurance will pay or the family will)); zero job security, I mean zero (they'll fire the best clinicians without a 2nd thought if they're paid too much or voice a contrary opinion; which reminds me: disagree with the status quo & you're labeled a trouble maker & your days are numbered (you're blackballed)--it happens all the time (disagree with a bozo superior--and there's a lot of em--and you just signed your death warrant).
The highest executives--Mishek, (especially) CFO Blaha, & the marketing/business people consider themselves light years above the rank and file. Funny, too, because they're the ones responsible for trashing both the Hazelden & Betty Ford brands in short order. It's a terrible shame, because it took decades to build those two reputations. That's the only thing the execs did with tremendous skill.
By the way: it's rumored that the good HBFF reviews on Glassdoor are 'plants' by the marketing department.

review_title: Passionate employees, undermined by incompetent middle management
job_title: Senior Psychologist in Center City, MN
pros: Committed 'in the trenches' workforce, admirable mission.  The campus is beautiful, the commute doesn't have heavy traffic, that's really about it.
cons:
Where to start?
1-Clinicians are paid below market median both nationally and for the state of MN
2-There is a definite glass ceiling for employees not in recovery.  Everyone knows who is and isn't because those who are talk about it incessantly, and go to the same meetings.
3-The most opaque management structure I've ever worked for.  No one knows who makes important decisions, or how said decisions were made.  When policies are changed, they are changed unilaterally, without input from employees who will actually be responsible for implementing the changes.
4-Related to # 3, when things go wrong, Hazelden is glacially slow at changing course
5-Despite espousing the use of empirically supported treatments, psychologists are given an absurd amount of latitude to do whatever they want, and so some of my former colleagues were/are practicing woefully outmoded treatment approaches.
6-Mercifully, the director of mental health was relieved of her duties a few months ago.  This has not staunched the bleeding of the massive brain drain that has happened the last 2 years, where the mental health department has had 50% turnover.  Those who left were all under 40, hungry, and highly productive.  Those who stayed were the ones getting away with doing as little work as possible under the old leadership.
7-The mental health department was not adequately staffed the entire 3+ years I worked there.
8-There have been numerous layoffs in the last 6 months, and it is only getting worse.

I could go on and on, but I think this is plenty.

job_title: Senior Clinician in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Great coworkers and strong bond with clients.

job_title: Recruiter in Center City, MN
pros:
During my time with HBFF, I worked in Center City but was lucky enough to visit multiple locations. Throughout every location I found that there was a unified energy of optimism. 
Employees of HBFF are incredibly busy, but will never miss the opportunity to stop and ask you about your day. The people here care. 

+Flexibility. The department that I worked in offered a lot of freedom regarding working from home and flexible hours. As long as you're able to hold yourself accountable and get work done, it won't be questioned. 
+Career Development. On my second week, the VP of HR asked me what my professional development goals were. Whether you want to advance to an HRBP position or enroll in grad school for addiction studies, they want to help you get there.
+Open Communication. Every other week I had a regular, standing meeting with my boss to discuss what's working, what's not, what's going on in our personal lives, frustrations, successes etc.  I always felt that I could be totally transparent and looked forward to these conversations. 
+Generous PTO. You get it 
+Visibility to other departments. Job shadowing is encouraged for everyone of every department. Internal hiring and promotion is celebrated. 
+Healthy Environment. Taking advantage of the walking trails, gym, pool, running track, library etc. is encouraged. 
+Dedication. Dedication to patient care and the overall well-being of employees. 
+Ability to be heard. Whether it be through "rounding" meetings, the employee engagement survey, Ethics Connection or the AskMark email address, they want to make sure that your opinions are heard.
cons: -I'm not sure if I would consider this a "con", but it was an adjustment for me. The amount of process and discussion that goes into every decision.

job_title: Licensed Chemical Dependency Counselor in Saint Paul, MN
pros: The Twelve Step program is excellent. There are some excellent employees who do care about the client. Unfortunately they are the exception rather than the rule.
cons: The culture has changed tremendously in the last 10 years.  It has evolved into a corporate business rather than a happy, caring entity.  It remains the most incestuous place I've ever known; people are hired (and fired) based on who they know.  Management is not trusted and in spite of  their lip service about employees being listened to, it doesn't happen.  Nursing is a disaster.  They are held in high esteem by upper management but many have ethical problems; lying about other employees is the norm and has cost quite a few their jobs.  As a retired licensed counselor I worked with other long-time employees who were also licensed; they were happy to "get out of there" and none have chosen to come back, even on an "on-call" basis.  That says a lot.  For a non-profit organization there are at least 18 employees who earn well over $200,000 per year, many of whom receive bonus and incentive compensation which an average employee might consider to be a nice yearly salary. And many of them are incompetent.  Employees are afraid to speak up about many things because they will be out the door pretty quickly, and they know it.  Human Resources is a joke and will not carry your concerns "up the ladder" because they're too embedded with management.

review_title: A corporate focus on "emotional resiliency" means one thing...
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Center City, MN
pros: The Campus is pretty, but look past the veneer. You'll see the age of everything pretty quickly
cons:
--Employee engagement scores have been horrible (and staying that way) every year for the past MANY years. While some feedback has stabilized in certain units, employees are widely dissatisfied, and when scores are released every year, there are a few months of focus on "fixing" things, with no REAL change ever happening. Upper management has no idea how to fix what is broken because it's upper management that's broken.
--Too much work and not enough investment, so workloads are horrible and there is no way to feel work/life balance. Not uncommon for upper management to EXPECT the average workweek is 50-60 hours and that people are always on. There are divisions that take great pride in people burning the candle at both ends. 
--For an organization that is supposed to help people "walk the talk" in recovery, I have never seen a bunch of "leaders" who simply refuse to practice what is preached. Leadership is supposed to follow "the Studer Way," and has meetings (mandatory) several times a year to reinforce those practices to staff. And yet leaders at the highest level of the organization don't follow them, and HR doesn't enforce them (this includes "leaders" making unilateral decisions hiring new team members that interviewing teams/committees have said no to) . When non-leaders point that out, they are often put in positions of retribution that essentially force attrition.
--Constant distraction by "shiny" things
--Leaders who have simply never worked anywhere else, so don't know which end is up and micromanage staff to overcompensate
--Complete lack of TRUE strategic plan and execution (though plans and strategy are discussed all the time)
--Toxic culture that is discussed and acknowledged all the time, but nothing is ever done about
--Meetings, meetings, meetings with no action, leaving little time for actual work
--Inability to practice what's core to the mission
--Horrible benefits (a wellness organization that offers no REAL wellness benefits? An EAP is really not a super supportive option for "wellness")
--Exceptionally little room for mobility and career progression
--A known "boys club"
--A weird combination of severe turn-over and attrition alongside employees who have been there 15, 20, 25, 30 years who have no other context and think dysfunction is normal.
--CONSTANT restructuring: not uncommon to have a different "leader" every year.  3 direct supervisors in three years is a direct example of poor executive management At one point, I didn't even have a  supervisor.
--No real job descriptions: no one has one,  and so no one knows how to actually be accountable. Execs refuse to take the time to write job docs and reconcile them for teams.
--As the headline indicates, when an organization is constantly pressing and reviewing on the "emotional resiliency" of employees (rather than trying to fix its culture), people should run. This only indicates that the organization's "mission" is to bleed employees dry, and then replace with staff that's fresh. It's called purposeful churn. Examples: Known discrepancies in salaries in the same departments that are not addressed, jobs suddenly being reorganized and cut down in responsibility but being paid more (without other jobs being balanced as well), and candidates being hired without the appropriate experience, but being paid more than experienced staff. When a person has "resiliency" with those scenarios...
--Complete disconnect between operating units creates chaos and resentment, and the entire organization is set up to be a healthcare operation, when many units have a healthcare focus, but are not healthcare operations.
